TITLE: The wonder of the fresh hop
By Lauren Frohne, Emily M. Eng and Tan Vinh
SUBHEAD

Fresh-hop beers are widely coveted, but few brewers can make them cheaper or fresher than in Washington state. Meet a world-renowned hop breeder and follow a star brewer's journey to create Washington’s true seasonal beer.
WORKING NOTES
TEXT / STEPS
The Yakima Valley is known as the hop haven of America.
The valley produces 75 percent of the hops in the United States and about a third of the world’s hops.

This is Perrault Farms, where fourth-generation hops farmer Jason Perrault breeds some of the most sought-after hops in America. Chances are good many of the IPAs you drink are made with Perrault’s hops.  Craft breweries consider him one of the most important figures in the beer world.
It's the first day of harvest and that means brewers are starting to make beers with fresh hops.
Fresh-hop beers use hops harvested from the field that morning. That vegetal, resinous scent after the harvest – similar to a freshly mown lawn – is what brewers try to harness into a “fresh beer.”
